entry.title: How to create a Purchase Order through BAPI in the SAP through program ( SE38 ) T-CODE .
entry.content:
1. Introduction:

In SAP ABAP, Purchase Orders (POs) can be created programmatically using standard BAPIs, which ensure data consistency and follow SAP business rules.
This blog explains how to create a Purchase Order using transaction SE38 by calling the standard BAPI BAPI_PO_CREATE1.

The example demonstrates:

  • Material number conversion

  • PO header and item population

  • Usage of HeaderX and ItemX structures

  • Error handling and transaction commit

 â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

 â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
 â”‚        End           â”‚
 â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

Program Declaration & Data Definitions:

Purpose

All required BAPI structures are declared for header, item, return messages, and output PO number.

DATA: wa_poheader   TYPE bapimepoheader,
      wa_poheaderx  TYPE bapimepoheaderx,
      it_poitem     TYPE TABLE OF bapimepoitem,
      it_poitemx    TYPE TABLE OF bapimepoitemx,
      wa_poitem     TYPE bapimepoitem,
      wa_poitemx    TYPE bapimepoitemx,
      it_bapiret2   TYPE TABLE OF bapiret2,
      wa_bapiret2   TYPE bapiret2,
      v_ebeln       TYPE bapimepoheader-po_number.

Explanation

  • BAPIMEPOHEADER â†’ PO header data

  • BAPIMEPOHEADERX â†’ Flags indicating which header fields are filled

  • BAPIMEPOITEM / ITEMX â†’ PO item data and change indicators

  • BAPIRET2 â†’ Return messages (success / error / warning)

Material Number Conversion 

Why Needed?

SAP stores material numbers internally in 18-character format with leading zeros.
To avoid errors, conversion is mandatory.

DATA: lv_matnr_raw  TYPE matnr,
      lv_matnr_conv TYPE matnr.

lv_matnr_raw = '93'.

CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERSION_EXIT_MATN1_INPUT'
  EXPORTING
    input  = lv_matnr_raw
  IMPORTING
    output = lv_matnr_conv.

 

Full Code to pass the Parameters and mandatory values while creating :

DATA: wa_poheader   TYPE bapimepoheader,
      wa_poheaderx  TYPE bapimepoheaderx,
      it_poitem     TYPE TABLE OF bapimepoitem,
      it_poitemx    TYPE TABLE OF bapimepoitemx,
      wa_poitem     TYPE bapimepoitem,
      wa_poitemx    TYPE bapimepoitemx,
      it_bapiret2   TYPE TABLE OF bapiret2,
      wa_bapiret2   TYPE bapiret2,
      v_ebeln       TYPE bapimepoheader-po_number.

DATA: lv_matnr_raw  TYPE matnr,
      lv_matnr_conv TYPE matnr.

* Convert material number to 18-digit (leading zero padding)
lv_matnr_raw = '93'.
CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERSION_EXIT_MATN1_INPUT'
  EXPORTING
    input  = lv_matnr_raw
  IMPORTING
    output = lv_matnr_conv.

* Fill PO Header
CLEAR wa_poheader.
wa_poheader-comp_code   = 'UN01'.
wa_poheader-doc_type    = 'NB'.
wa_poheader-purch_org   = 'UN04'.
wa_poheader-pur_group   = '001'.
wa_poheader-vendor      = 'TATA STEEL'.
wa_poheader-langu       = sy-langu.
wa_poheader-item_intvl  = '00010'.
wa_poheader-created_by  = sy-uname.
wa_poheader-currency    = 'INR'.

* Fill HeaderX
CLEAR wa_poheaderx.
wa_poheaderx-comp_code   = 'X'.
wa_poheaderx-doc_type    = 'X'.
wa_poheaderx-purch_org   = 'X'.
wa_poheaderx-pur_group   = 'X'.
wa_poheaderx-vendor      = 'X'.
wa_poheaderx-langu       = 'X'.
wa_poheaderx-item_intvl  = 'X'.
wa_poheaderx-created_by  = 'X'.
wa_poheaderx-currency    = 'X'.

* Only one item â€” no loop needed here unless dynamic
CLEAR wa_poitem.
wa_poitem-po_item     = '00010'.
wa_poitem-short_text  = 'STELL'.
wa_poitem-quantity    = '2000'.
wa_poitem-orderpr_un  = 'KG'.
wa_poitem-material    = lv_matnr_conv.
wa_poitem-plant       = 'UN02'.
APPEND wa_poitem TO it_poitem.

CLEAR wa_poitemx.
wa_poitemx-po_item     = '00010'.
wa_poitemx-short_text  = 'X'.
wa_poitemx-quantity    = 'X'.
wa_poitemx-orderpr_un  = 'X'.
wa_poitemx-material    = 'X'.
wa_poitemx-plant       = 'X'.
APPEND wa_poitemx TO it_poitemx.

* Call BAPI
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PO_CREATE1'
  EXPORTING
    poheader         = wa_poheader
    poheaderx        = wa_poheaderx
  IMPORTING
    exppurchaseorder = v_ebeln
  TABLES
    return           = it_bapiret2
    poitem           = it_poitem
    poitemx          = it_poitemx.

* Check creation
IF v_ebeln IS NOT INITIAL.
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT'
    EXPORTING
      wait = 'X'.
  WRITE: / 'Purchase Order Created:', v_ebeln.
ELSE.
  LOOP AT it_bapiret2 INTO wa_bapiret2 WHERE type = 'E' OR type = 'A'.
    WRITE: / 'Error:', wa_bapiret2-message.
  ENDLOOP.
ENDIF.

  • All mandatory fields required for Purchase Order creation must be populated in the PO Header and PO Item structures; otherwise, the BAPI will return error messages.

  • For every field filled in POHEADER or POITEM, the corresponding field in POHEADERX and POITEMX must be marked with 'X'.
    If the X indicator is missing, the BAPI will ignore the value, even if it is provided.

  • Header data Company Code, Vendor, Purchasing Organization, Currency, etc. controls the overall PO, while Item data Material, Quantity, Plant, UOM, etc. defines line-level details.

  • Material numbers must be passed in internal SAP format 18-character format with leading zeros. Use the relevant conversion exit to avoid material-related errors.

  • Always check the RETURN table BAPIRET2 after calling the BAPI to identify errors, warnings, or success messages.

  • The Purchase Order is not saved automatically after BAPI execution.
    You must explicitly call BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT to reflect the PO in standard SAP tables EKKO, EKPO, etc.

  • Use WAIT = 'X' in the commit function to ensure the transaction is completed before further processing.

  • If errors TYPE = 'E' or TYPE = 'A' are returned, the commit should not be executed, and the error messages should be displayed or logged.

  • Always validate the generated PO number before confirming successful creation.

    • This BAPI-based approach ensures data consistency, follows SAP standard validation logic, and is recommended over direct table updates.

      Final Output:

      After successful execution of the SE38 report, the system generates a Purchase Order number.
      You can cross-check this output by navigating to SE37, where the same PO number can be passed to validate and review the Purchase Order details.

      Conclusion:

      Using BAPI_PO_CREATE1 in SE38 is a safe and SAP-recommended approach to create Purchase Orders programmatically.
      By correctly filling Header and Item structures, handling material conversion, and committing the transaction, we can ensure reliable PO creation.

      This method is ideal for:

      • Interface programs

      • File-based uploads

      • Mass PO creation

      • Integration scenarios


Thank You ..

Chandu Kumar.

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud Storie Visualization
entry.content: In a SuccessFactors live model, SAP Analytics Cloud shows only the code because the Department name is stored as a text attribute and not exposed as a display attribute by default, so SAC consumes only the technical key, and to resolve this you must enable the Department name as a text or description attribute in the SuccessFactors data source or use the option to display key and text together if available, otherwise SAC cannot show the name instead of the code.

entry.title: Re: How to add F4 in Standard Fiori Apps for extended SAP Standard fields
entry.content: Is there a way to achieve this as for my case the value help button is greyed out in custom fields app.

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud session cookies remain after corp...
entry.content: This behavior is expected when SAP Analytics Cloud is embedded via iFrame because SAC session cookies are browser based and are not automatically cleared when the corporate IdP logs the user out, so even though the IdP session is terminated the SAC session remains active until the browser is closed, and Cloud Identity Services does not propagate a front channel logout to invalidate SAC cookies in this scenario, so a new user can inherit the previous SAC session, and there is no supported way to force SAC to delete cookies from an external logout, so the recommended workarounds are to enforce browser close on logout, use private or isolated browser sessions, or redesign the embedding with proper logout handling and session isolation at the application level.

4) Activate the program and test in VF01, VF02 and VF03 transactions

If you require more detail information please let me know.

Regards,

entry.title: Re: How are you leveraging SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) for...
entry.content: Companies use SAP Analytics Cloud to create instant reports by connecting live or imported data models and building interactive stories with real time filters and charts, and they predict future trends by using built in predictive features such as time series forecasting, smart predict, and planning models that analyze historical data and simulate future outcomes for better decision making.

entry.title: Re: Sap analytic cloud aggregation
entry.content: In SAP Analytics Cloud this happens because the model is already at a more detailed grain than WBS, so SAC repeats the PO amount across rows and cannot deduplicate it automatically, and creating another aggregated measure on the same data will still return the same value, so the correct solution is to aggregate the PO amount at the source or model level using the unique combination of WBS, PO number, PO product, and PO serial, for example by creating a pre aggregated table or BW query, because SAC cannot recalculate a budget correctly when duplicate transactional rows already exist in the model.

entry.title: No nightmare before Christmas - our SAC carol ğŸ„
entry.content:
Santaâ€™s Journey

"Holly, jolly Christmas! Yeah, right... more like gloomy doomy, based on the numbers. Who can keep up with that?" - another year Santa is desperately studying all the certain and uncertain details of his ambitious Christmas Eve tour.
Simply having a manual process (â€¦ far from wonderful) makes it difficult to adapt to sudden snowstorms, last-minute gift list changes, reindeer fatigue, and even unexpected chimney blockages. Last Christmas, Santa gave all his â€œheartâ€ work and almost gave it away. This year, to save him from tears, heâ€™d give it to someone special.
Having a word with himself: â€œYou better watch out, you better not cry. You will find a solution.â€
Heâ€™s browsing the Internet when he suddenly hears the herald angels sing: SAP â€“ Santa Application Products. He calls immediately â€¦
What can we say, who corrects Santa, right? Especially, since we have the perfect solution for Analytics and Planning: SAP Analytics Cloud 

So, Santa called - seeking for help, to plan his ambitious Christmas Eve tour. Naturally, we pulled up the sleeves, getting to work and started with the natural step #1: our data model:

Thanks to our harmonized model and the seamless planning integration, the model can be easily created and directly integrated with SAP Datasphere.

Santaâ€™s planning sheet has already provided a few details and seems to outline a driver-based model. We will need to factor in households, the miles those reindeer have to cover, and of course some time for the actual gift drop â€“ and plus a little extra for those delicious cookies of yours ğŸªğŸ§‹.

Other influencing factors? Well, there is the â€œWeather Delay Factorâ€ or the â€œReindeer Fatigue Rateâ€ because even Rudolph needs a break. And of course, the â€œMagic Time Compression Factorâ€ â€“ we need to be real here, how else could Santa deliver that many packages in just one night. ğŸ•°ï¸

This leaves us with the following model structure (shown here as an account dimension but measure calculations would work equally):

Calculations allow us to report, simulate and optimize a wide range of metrics and key KPIs, such as the overall â€œOn Time Indicatorâ€! Inverse formulas allow top-down planning, so Santa can set those ambitious goals (like optimizing the time needed before â€œmagicâ€):

With the flexible hierarchy management tool, we can easily separate drivers and KPIs and thanks to multi-language support, SantaÂ´s helpers can work in their native tongue.

Once the model is set up, we continue with step 2: the data. Thankfully, Santa has provided all his handwritten plans from previous years, so we can use the integrated Business User File Upload to populate our model â€“ based on the sheet Santa provided!

Now, with all the data transferred into the model, Santa can get to work: All the magic built-into the model is already functioning - calculations are performed and the â€œOn time indicatorâ€ (KPI Threshold) highlights areas that need his attention. With an ad hoc generated Value Driver Tree, Santa gets a clear overview over his model structure, all drivers and KPIs, even input-enabled options for simulations right at the model level. And the drill-down feature allows breakdowns of certain drivers into the various dimensions (e.g. Region).

Also, a dedicated report allows Santa to quickly navigate through the different regions:

Oh, oh! In Europe the â€œOn Time Indicatorâ€ is off â€“ time for a new scenario sheet, allowing Santa to adjust those drivers and optimize, so we can be on time for Europe as well!

A Client Calculation â€œDeltaâ€ helps to identify the adjustments made, and a new version â€Scenario Aâ€ allows various simulation scenarios without changing the data in public data sets. This way, only proven adjustments are submitted to the final plan and made available to everyone. The weather forecast for Europe indicates a cold but calm and clear night, so the â€œWeather Delay Factorâ€ can be adjusted! ItÂ´s also a good time to test that new Reindeer Power Granulate, bringing the â€œFatigue Rateâ€ down â€“ our Reindeers will have more energy! With just a few slight adjustments the â€œOn Time Indicatorâ€ is back to where it should be! Plan confirmed and submitted â€“ with extra care for certain regions bringing Santa back on track!

As we still have a few uncertainties, Santa needs to gain more confidence: How ambitious is the plan, or in other words, how likely will he reach his goal (or is it our goal ğŸ˜‰)? Luckily, right from the simulation table, by selecting the key KPI (â€œTotal Time Requiredâ€), he can run a Monte Carlo Simulation using SAC Compass. After adjusting the drivers (which uncertainties do we want to simulate?) and setting the right corridor, e.g. we have a hard limit at 24hours, Compass will present us with the result:

Wohoo! After running tens of thousands of simulations across all the magical drivers, the results are in: Santa has a 68% chance of hitting his target! Thanks to the tight integration of simulation and planning, we can say with a certain level of confidence â€¦ ğŸ¥ : Christmas is saved for another year! The sleigh is ready, the reindeer are fueled up, and the data magic worked its wonders.

Now behind the scenes, the elves are already preparing the 2nd version using built-in capabilities, including:

  • Datasphere Integration / Live Versions â€“ to leverage various data sources and the tight integration via seamless planning
  • Asymmetric Reporting â€“ comparing budget, plan and forecasts
  • MyMetrics â€“ to really manage that important KPIs
  • Predictive Forecasting â€“ project potential forecasts and uncertainties, pre-fill plans allowing faster simulation and insights
  • An Excel-Frontend, allowing convenience features in Microsoft Excel paired with the power of an integrated, in-cloud planning solution

but we will leave that for another episode (and evolution of our planning application)! ğŸ˜‰

 

Merry Christmas everyone! ğŸ…ğŸ„

entry.title: Re: Certificate Expire Notifications Alert in SAP Cloud Integration - iFlow
entry.content:
If anyone encounter issues accessing OData via a free trial account, follow these steps:

  1. Create a Service Key with the correct plan:

    • Navigate to Service Marketplace â†’ SAP Process Integration Runtime.
    • Create a Service Key using the API plan (not the integration-flow plan).

  2. Verify connectivity using Postman:

    • Use the URL:
      https://<tmn-url>/api/v1/$metadata
    • Select OAuth 2.0 authentication with Client Credentials grant type.
    • Use the credentials from your newly created service key to generate an access token.
    • Apply the token as a Bearer Token to fetch the metadata.

  3. Configure your OData adapter:

    • Use the same credentials from the service key in your OData adapter configuration.
    • This will ensure successful connectivity.

entry.title: SAC SSO: Merging existing users without losing content
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

we have IAS configured as a proxy. Users are provisioned from a custom IdP to IAS and then created dynamically in SAC (attribute = User ID) via SSO .

In SAC, there are already manually created users with existing content.
The SSO users and the manually created users in SAC have different User IDs, which is historical.

Our goal is to switch fully to SSO and replace or merge the existing SAC users without losing user content (stories, private objects, settings).

Currently, we face the following issues:

  • SAC does not allow duplicate email addresses when a new SSO user is created (different User ID, but same email address).

  • When we assign roles manually in SAC to an SSO user, they are removed at the next login.

Our questions:

  • What is the recommended approach to dynamically create SSO users in SAC and transfer or replace existing content from the old user to the new SSO user?

  • Is there a simple or supported way to migrate or merge existing SAC users with the new SSO users?

  • How are Owner property handled when SSO is activated, and what should be considered to avoid issues with access or content ownership?

Thank you very much for your help and experience.

Best regards

entry.title: Re: You only have display authorization in PE02
entry.content:
Resolution

  1. Run t-code SE38 to execute report RPUCTF00 under the following conditions:
    Personnel calculation rules: Enter the name of the Personnel calculation Rule.
    Set editor lock: Ensure the 'Set editor lock' checkbox is not selected. 
    Test: Enter 'OFF'.

  2. Click execute button and the log is displayed.

  3. Display the attribute of the Personnel calculation Rule via t-code PE02 and verify that the 'Changes only by person responsible' checkbox is not selected. 

  4. The Personnel Calculation Rule can now be modified using t-code PE02 without encountering an error message.

 

Kamal Kant

entry.title: Period-End Closing (PEC) utility posting to Main Branch instead of individual branches - SAP B1
entry.content:
Hello experts,

We are using SAP Business One 10.0 SP 2505 with the Multiple Branches feature enabled. We are encountering an issue with how the Period-End Closing utility handles branch-specific balances.

The Issue

When running the Period-End Closing utility, we selected All Branches in the selection criteria. The system successfully generated the two standard Journal Entries:

  1. Closing Entry: P&L Accounts > Period-End Closing Account.

  2. Final Entry: Period-End Closing Account > Retained Earnings Account.

The Problem: Both Journal Entries were automatically assigned to the Main Branch.

The Impact on Reporting

  • Consolidated Trial Balance: Shows the correct zeroed-out balances for P&L accounts.

  • Individual Branch Trial Balance: When we run the TB for a specific sub-branch, the P&L accounts still show balances because the closing JEs were posted to the Main Branch instead of the sub-branch.

Questions for the Community

  1. Is it a requirement to run the Period-End Closing utility separately for each individual branch to ensure the JEs are tagged with the correct Branch ID?

  2. Is there a setting in G/L Account Determination or Branch Setup that allows a single PEC run to "split" the resulting JEs by branch automatically?

  3. If we must run it branch-by-branch, what is the best practice for the Retained Earnings accountâ€”should we have a separate RE account per branch, or is one central account standard?

Any advice on the standard workflow for multi-branch period-end closing would be very helpful.

entry.title: IDoc with Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh using the Event Add-On
entry.content:
In modern SAP landscapes, Intermediate Documents (IDocs) remain a foundational pillar for reliable, standardized data exchangeâ€”both within SAP systems and between SAP and external systems. The Event Add-on extends this proven SAP mechanism into today's heterogeneous and event-driven integration architectures by enabling bidirectional IDoc messaging that is code-less, real-time, and flexible. With the Add-On, standard and custom SAP IDocs can not only be processed in their native format but also converted on-the-fly to JSON for seamless delivery to cloud platforms, messaging brokers, or event-driven consumers, and vice versa. This empowers organizations to leverage established SAP interfaces while bridging to modern integration patterns without heavy custom development.

Please also check out the technology comparison in our central blog.

Create Logical System

  • Transaction: SALE
  • Select the created Connection
  • Go to section Basic Settings â†’ Define Logical System
  • Add New Entry and specify:
    • Log.System: Name has to be â€œLOCALâ€
    • Name: choose a description

Create Customer Distribution Model

  • Transaction: BD64
  • Create Model View and specify:
    • Sender: Sending client
    • Recipients: Logical system (LOCAL)
    • Add message type as required (e.g., MATMAS)

Create IDoc Port

  • Transaction: WE21
  • Select the created Connection
  • Go to section ABAP-PI
  • Add New Entry and specify:
    • Port: choose a name (e.g., ACI_IDOC)
    • Description: choose a description
    • Function module: /ASADEV/ACI_IDOC_PORT_TRIGGER

Create Partner profiles

Note:

Make sure a Distribution model is available (Transaction BD64)

  • Transaction: WE20
  • Open folder: Partner Type LS
  • Go to section Outbound Options.
    • Receiver port: ACI_IDOC
    • Basic Type: MATMAS07

Create Outbound Object

Note:

In the example below, we want to trigger an outbound message for SAP material master IDocs (IDoc name â€œMATMASâ€), convert the IDoc payload to JSON and send it to an event broker instance.

  • Transaction: SPRO
  • Goto ASAPIO Cloud Integrator â†’ Connection and Replication Object Customizing
  • Or go directly to transaction: /ASADEV/68000202
  • Select the created Connection
  • Go to section Outbound Objects
  • Add New Entry and specify:
    • Object: name of the outbound configuration
    • Extraction Func. Module: /ASADEV/ACI_GEN_VIEW_EXTRACTOR
    • Message Type: Specific message type (Example: Z_SAP_EM_MATMAS)
    • Load Type: Incremental Load
    • Trace: activate for testing purposes
    • Extraction view name: EDID4
  • Formatting Function: /ASADEV/ACI_GEN_IDOC_FORMATTER

Set up â€˜Event Linkageâ€™

Link the configuration of the outbound object to a Business Object event:

  • Navigate to Outbound Objects â†’ Event Linkage or use transaction SWE2.
  • Add New Entry and specify:
    • Object Category: BO BOR Object Type
    • Object Type: /ASADEV/ID
    • Event: ACI_TRIGGER_EVENT
    • Receiver Function Module: /ASADEV/ACI_EVENTS_TRIGGER
    • Linkage Activated: tick the checkbox
    • Check Function Module: /ASADEV/ACI_EVENTS_CHECK

 

Set-up â€˜Header Attributesâ€™

Specific for the IDoc Outbound use-case you have to specify the header attributes. For all details check https://asapio.com/docs/idoc/.

Test the outbound IDoc event creation

Start transaction BD10 to test the described formatter

Welcome you IDoc event in SAP AEM using Try-Me.

Stay tuned and Happy Eventing

entry.title: Re: Two different subtotals for a Rebate condition contract
entry.content: No, you cannot assign two different rebate bases (Net vs. Gross) within a single condition contract in the Settlement Data tab â€” it only allows one basis field. To achieve mixed bases, you need to configure multiple contracts or leverage Business Volume Profiles with split criteria. The "Amount Fields â€“ Split Criteria" option lets you define how business volume is split (e.g., by material group, customer hierarchy, or custom fields) so that rebate calculations can be differentiated across items

entry.title: F0266A indicates redundant data
entry.content:
Application F0266A (Delayed Production Orders - MRP) displays redundant data.

entry.title: Re: SAP Certification Transformation: How You Can Get and Stay Certified
entry.content:
@Anna-Lena_Juergens 

They're different things, one is to Get Certified and the other one is to Stay Certified.

With your SAP Learning Hub subscription you have up to 4 attempts per year to Get Certified, which means that if you are planning to become an SAP Certified Consultant in Employee Central or Performance and Goals, you can use these attempts to complete the assessment (question-based proctored exam until the end of the year, and scenario-based or system-based from 2026 onwards).

Once you pass your certification assessment and Get Certified, you need to ensure to validate your certified status every year. Every release we publish a Stay Certified assessment to include the most relevant enhancements, as a question-based (usually around 10 questions), and this assessment can be taken as many times as needed, until you pass (normally 80% or 100%, based on the number of questions). 

Once you pass the Stay Certified assessment, your "Stay certified due" date will be extended for another year. You can check your date in https://learning.sap.com/my-learning/certifications and access Manage Certification. Always make sure to not miss this date! Otherwise, your certification would expire and you would have to Get Certified again. 

You can take the Stay Certified assessment every release (recommended), or skip one assessment and take the following one, that's the reason why the certification validation is for 1 year, and every time you pass a Stay Certified, the renewal date will be for another year. 

Hope this helps to clarify, 

Regards, 

Jordi

entry.title: Capgemini Chosen to Pilot SAPâ€™s Newly Launched SAP Business AI Solutions Operations Certification
entry.content:
When SAP introduced its new SAP Business AI solutions operations certification, it signaled a new differentiator for partners driving the next wave of enterprise AI innovation. At the intersection of readiness and opportunity, Capgemini was selected as pilot partner - reflecting years of trust, operational maturity, and leadership in SAP Business AI. In this story, SAP and Capgemini share their perspectives on how co-creation, real-world rigor, and precise timing helped shape a new standard for AI operations. Together, they highlight what it takes to turn innovation into trusted, enterprise-grade reality.

 

SAPâ€™s Perspective

In the rapidly evolving landscape of enterprise AI, operational excellence is no longer a back-office concern, itâ€™s a strategic imperative. Thatâ€™s why SAP launched its new certification â€œSAP-certified in SAP Business AI solutions operationsâ€, designed to validate and elevate the operational capabilities of partners delivering services and AI-powered operations for SAP.

For this initiative, SAP chose Capgemini as its first pilot partner. The decision was rooted in trust, history, and proven excellence and some fortunate timing. Capgemini was due to recertify its operations certifications, and the timing aligned with SAPâ€™s desire to pilot a new certification for SAP Business AI operations. Capgeminiâ€™s maturity in the SAP Business AI space made them an ideal pilot partner. Their defined offerings, mature KPIs, and well-managed AI operations gave SAP the confidence to move forward with the certification launch.

â€œAs we scale Business AI across the enterprise, trust in the operations behind it is just as critical as the technology itself. Having Capgemini as our pilot partner for this certification was a deliberate choice; their operational maturity and candid feedback helped elevate our new standards for the entire ecosystem.â€,
said Marc-Oliver Klein, VP, Head of Partner Product Management SAP Business AI, SAP SE.

What made this collaboration truly special was Capgeminiâ€™s active role in shaping the certification itself. Their feedback helped refine the final form of the certification. Their thoughtful feedback helped turn it into something that truly mirrors real-world operational needs. Itâ€™s another milestone in a long-standing partnership between SAP and Capgemini.

                                                                                                   

Capgeminiâ€™s Perspective

When SAP approached Capgemini to recertify its operations scope, they were already deep into their AI journey, with a strong posture in SAP AI operations and a desire to further validate their capabilities.

Participating in the pilot wasnâ€™t just about earning a badge, it was about co-creating a standard that would define operational excellence in AI for years to come. Capgeminiâ€™s willingness to engage, provide feedback, and iterate with SAP reflects its commitment to being a trusted, forward-thinking partner.

"Partnering with SAP on this new certification allowed us to go beyond validation. It enabled us to help define what excellence in AI operations truly looks like. Itâ€™s a proud moment that reflects our shared commitment to shaping the future with our clients, making it real.",  
said Gianluca Simeone, VP - Global SAP CTIO and Gen-AI Leader at Capgemini.

This certification now stands as a symbol of Capgeminiâ€™s leadership in the space and its dedication to robust, scalable, and high-performing AI operations. It also reinforces Capgeminiâ€™s role in helping shape the future of enterprise AI alongside SAP.

 

 

 

Information on the certification program for operations partners and an overview of all certified partners can be found in the SAP Operations Partner Guide.

Visit OPC at SAP.com or on the SAP Partner Portal.

entry.title: Re: Measure based Range filter not working as expected in...
entry.content: In SAP Analytics Cloud this is a known limitation where measure based filters by range do not fully work on calculated measures in combination charts, especially stacked column and line charts, even though the same filter works correctly in tables, because charts apply calculations after aggregation and the filter logic is evaluated differently, so the recommended workaround is to apply the filter on base measures, convert the calculation into a model level measure, or use a table as the driving widget with linked analysis instead of relying on a chart level measure filter.

entry.title: Re: PR still showing as commitment after PO creation in c...
entry.content:
Hi @VIBHUTI_CHAUHAN ,
When a Purchase Requisition and its followâ€‘on Purchase Order both appear as active commitments for the same WBS element, it almost always means SAP is not reducing the PR commitment when the PO is created. This can be caused by configuration gaps, masterâ€‘data inconsistencies, or technical issues in the commitment update logic. Please Check Commitment Update Activation. Goto SPRO â†’ Controlling â†’ General Controlling â†’ Activate Commitment Management. Ensure the following are active, Commitment Management for CO and Commitment Management for Purchasing. If PR or PO is not flagged as commitmentâ€‘relevant, SAP will not reduce commitments correctly.

Check Account Assignment Category, In PR and PO. Account assignment category must be P (Project) or Q (Project Stock) or K (Cost Center) depending on your setup. WBS element must be valid, released, and commitmentâ€‘relevant. If the PO has a different WBS or missing account assignment, the PR commitment will not be reduced.

Check Document Flow In ME53N (PR) â†’ Environment â†’ Document Overview. Ensure the PO is properly linked to the PR item. If the link is missing, SAP cannot reduce the PR commitment. Check Reduction Indicator in PR Item In PR item â†’ Delivery/Invoice tab Field, "Commitment Reduction" must be active (usually automatic).

entry.title: Re: Blending Charts on Optimized Stories | SAP Analytics...
entry.content: In the optimized design experience this is a known limitation because linked dimensions must be part of the chart to enable data blending, unlike the classic story where this was more flexible, so there is no supported way to hide or exclude the linked dimension from the chart, and the recommended approaches are to redesign the model to include a common dimension, pre blend the data in the source such as BW or Datasphere, or use a table or helper widget to drive linked analysis, since moving back to classic experience is the only way to achieve the old behavior but it is not recommended going forward.

entry.title: Re: S_ALR_87012284 Plan version Hard currency comparison...
entry.content:
Hi @Vijay_Adwani93 ,
I think what changed After the S/4HANA 2023 Upgrade The Plan Version Became a Required Selection SAP introduced a new requirement where certain classic reports now expect a plan version to be explicitly entered. If you donâ€™t enter a plan version, the system suppresses hardâ€‘currency values entirely â€” both for the reporting and comparison periods. The other possibility is Plan Version â€œ0â€ Only Partially Works, When you enter Plan Version 0, hardâ€‘currency values appear for the reporting period but not for the comparison period*. This suggests that the comparison period logic is not correctly reading plan version data after the upgrade. What could be the reason, why Hardâ€‘Currency Values Fail in the Comparison Period Based on SAPâ€™s currency framework in S/4HANA, Hard currency (type 40) is derived at the ledger level, not the plan version level.

Classic reports (like S_ALR_87012284) still rely on older logic that expects plan data to exist for both periods. After the upgrade, SAP changed how plan version filtering interacts with currency types â€” and the comparison period logic appears to be missing the hardâ€‘currency read. This aligns with known complexities in S/4HANAâ€™s multiâ€‘currency setup, where currency types, ledgers, and plan data must align for reporting to work consistently

Check whether plan version 0 has plan data for the comparison period. Even if you donâ€™t use planning, the report may still expect entries. Test with another plan version (e.g., 1) If hardâ€‘currency values appear for both periods with another version, the issue is isolated to version 0.

Run report with â€œNo Plan Versionâ€ in older system, If it worked before the upgrade, this strengthens the case for an SAP regression. Or Else Raise an SAP Incident. Given that others have reported the same issue, SAP may already be preparing a correction note.

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud: Issue with 000 period from ACDOC...
entry.content: This behavior is expected because in ACDOCU the field FISCYEARPER can be 000 for postings that are not assigned to a fiscal period such as opening balances or special postings, and SAP Analytics Cloud rejects period 000 as an invalid time member, so the solution is to handle this at the source by filtering out FISCYEARPER equal to 000 in the CDS view, or mapping it to a valid period if business logic allows, because SAC does not provide an option to accept or convert period 000 at model or story level.

entry.title: Re: Stock Transfer Order between plants in SAP S/4HANA Pu...
entry.content:
Dear @vicentejarque,

In Public Cloud the confirmation control key (BSTAE) is not determined by a customizing table like on-prem Define Order Confirmation for Delivery per document type

Instead SAP says the system fills BSTAE by a fixed priority:

  1. Reference document
  2. Info record
  3. Supplier master
    This priority is the same when creating a Purchase Order

So if you maintain BSTAE in BP but it stays empty, itâ€™s usually because (a) the supplier logic is not used for your STO type or (b) an info record/reference exists and is blank and it wins by priority

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2868471

How to default 0004 (Inbound Delivery) in Public Cloud:

Option A (standard / recommended)

Use UD or copy of UD then maintain BSTAE= 0004 where itâ€™s picked up by the priority rules:

  • Manage Purchasing Info Records app best, because it has higher priority than supplier

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F1982')/S35

Option B if you must keep UB

Then you typically need Custom Logic (Badi) to set BSTAE during PO creation. SAP lists the PO Badis available in Public Cloud:

  • MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM
  • MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_HEADER
  • BD_MMPUR_FINAL_CHECK_PO

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3451258

Summary:

  • Where to configure it like on-prem per doc type? Not available in Public Cloud, defaulting follows SAP priority rule like on SAP Note above
  • Can you default 0004 for STO? Yes, most cleanly by using UD or UD copy + maintain info record  for UB you likely need Badi

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Data masking, data scrambling and data anonymization in Business Data Cloud with SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • 1 - Generalities
  • 1.1 - Data masking
  • 1.2 - Data scrambling
  • 1.2.1 - Create function
  • 1.2.2 - Expose table data
  • 1.2.3 - Create a view
  • 1.2.4 - Import the view into Datasphere
  • 1.3 - Data anonymization
  • 2 - Standardization
  • 2.1 - Parameters table
  • 2.2 - SQL Procedures
  • 2.2.1 - Procedure EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT
  • 2.2.1 - Procedure EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR
  • 2.2.2 - Procedure EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR
  • 2.3 - Task Chain
  • 2.3.1 - Grant permissions
  • 2.3.2 - Create a task chain
  • 2.3.3 - Test
  • Conclusion

 

Introduction

This blog post was inspired from: How Data Anonymization in SAP HANA secure Generative AI applications through SAP Datasphere 

Here you will find a description of generalities about:

  • masking, scrambling and anonymization features
  • how to automate the creation of views with data masking, data scrambling and data anonymization and the possibility to activate/deactivate some features in the target views.

SAP Datasphere contains a lot of features. Some are accessible directly via its user interface and others are accessible via Open SQL Schema (see SAP Datasphere help site). Open SQL Schema gives you access to the underlying SAP HANA Cloud database, and extends the capacities offered via Datasphere's UI.

In this blog, we use a Datasphere space called DEMO with the database user DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE.

We will use a Datasphere local table SALARY as an example dataset where we would like to:

  • mask the CREDIT_CARD column and rename the column to CREDIT_CARD_MASKED,
  • scramble the NAME column and rename the column to NAME_SCRAMBLED,
  • anonymize the SALARY column and rename the column to SALARY_ANONYMIZED

 

 

 

 

 

Save the content below to import a sample dataset into the SALARY local table.

"ID","NAME","GENDER","CITY","SALARY","CREDIT_CARD"
"1","Paul McCartney","M","Levallois","1002.32","1111-1111-1111-1111"
"2","Martin Solveig","M","Munich","3218.21","2222-2222-2222-2222"
"3","Nils Lofgren","M","Nice","1398.32","3333-3333-3333-3333"
"4","Annika","F","Munich","2053.23","4444-4444-4444-4444"

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

1 - Generalities

1.1 - Data masking

Data masking is a feature implemented into SAP HANA Cloud (see Data Masking).
In this blog, we will not use privileges to manage masking, but simply use calculated SQL expressions when defining views where some columns should be masked.

To mask the content of the NAME column, we can just use the following SQL Statement into an SQL view object in Datasphere :

SELECT "ID",
   "NAME",
   CITY,
   GENDER,
   SALARY,
   LEFT(CREDIT_CARD, 4) || '-XXXX-XXXX-' || RIGHT(CREDIT_CARD, 4) AS CREDIT_CARD_MASKED
FROM SALARY

The content displayed by the view is:

 

 

 

 

1.2 - Data scrambling

To scramble characters in a string, a function needs to be created in the Open SQL Schema DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE (the one automatically created by Datasphere when creating the database user). To connect to this schema, SAP HANA Database Explorer can be started from the space management window:

 

 

 

 

 

1.2.1 - Create function

Once in data Database explorer, the function SCRAMBLE_STRING can be created:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Copy/Paste the following code:

CREATE FUNCTION SCRAMBLE_STRING (IN input NVARCHAR(500))
RETURNS scrambled NVARCHAR(500)
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
AS
BEGIN
    DECLARE len INT = LENGTH(:input);
    DECLARE temp NVARCHAR(500) = :input;
    DECLARE result NVARCHAR(500) = '';
    DECLARE pos INT;
 
    WHILE LENGTH(:temp) > 0 DO
        pos := CEIL(RAND() * LENGTH(:temp));  -- Pick random position
        result := result || SUBSTRING(:temp, :pos, 1); -- Append character
        temp := REPLACE(:temp, SUBSTRING(:temp, :pos, 1), ''); -- Remove picked char
    END WHILE;
 
    scrambled := result;
  END

1.2.2 - Expose table data

Since Datasphere local tables cannot be directly exposed, in order to be able to read the content of the SALARY table when using an Open SQL Schema, a view V_SALARY needs to be created in Datasphere using the Data Builder:

SELECT "ID",
	"NAME",
	"GENDER",
	"CITY",
	"SALARY",
	"CREDIT_CARD"
FROM "SALARY"

1.2.3 - Create a view

A view V_SALARY_SCRAMBLED can now be created using Database Explorer to scramble the column NAME from the  V_SALARY view (the call to INITCAP function was just added to format names):

CREATE VIEW "V_SALARY_NAME_SCRAMBLED" AS
(SELECT 
	"ID" AS "ID",
	INITCAP(SCRAMBLE_STRING("NAME")) AS NAME_SCRAMBLED,
	GENDER AS GENDER,
	CITY AS CITY,
	SALARY,
	CREDIT_CARD
FROM DEMO.V_SALARY);

1.2.4 - Import the view into Datasphere

You can now import the view to create a Datasphere local table: start the process to create a dummy Datasphere view, select the Sources tab in the source browser, then click on the schema name and Drag and Drop of the View name to the text area. This triggers the table import, click on Import an Deploy, then close the New SQL View object (no need to save it, click on Discard):

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Now, the view "DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE".V_SALARY_SCRAMBLED can be opened and used in Datasphere:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

1.3 - Data anonymization

The SAP HANA Data Anonymization Guide explains how to anonymize data. In this blog, we will not focus on the technique used to anonymize data, but rather on sample syntax used to anonymize data. The following SQL code creates a view with the anonymized SALARY column (the view with anonymization will be effective after the REFRESH command):

CREATE VIEW "V_SALARY_SALARY_ANONYMIZED" AS
(SELECT 
	"ID",
	"NAME",
	GENDER,
	CITY,
	SALARY AS SALARY_ANONYMIZED,
	CREDIT_CARD
FROM DEMO.V_SALARY)
WITH ANONYMIZATION(
	ALGORITHM 'DIFFERENTIAL_PRIVACY'
	PARAMETERS '{"data_change_strategy": "qualified"}'
	COLUMN "ID" PARAMETERS '{"is_sequence": true}'
	COLUMN "SALARY_ANONYMIZED" PARAMETERS '{"is_sensitive":true, "epsilon":0.1, "sensitivity":2000}'
);
REFRESH VIEW "V_SALARY_SALARY_ANONYMIZED" ANONYMIZATION;

The V_SALARY_SALARY_ANONYMIZED view can now be imported into Datasphere (see 1.2.4 - Import the view into Datasphere)

 

2 - Standardization

We've seen above that Open SQL Schema is powerful to create features not implemented in the Datasphere UI but accessible using SQL.

The standardization will allow the SAP Datasphere users to easily activate/deactivate masking, scrambling and anonymization for columns.
A Datasphere local table (VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS) will contain the views definitions and a custom SQL procedure (EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR) will read its content to create the views based on the stored definitions. Then a Task Chain will be created to call the procedure from Datasphere.

2.1 - Parameters table

The table "VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS" will have the following columns:
  • "TARGET_VIEW": name of the view that will be created in the Open SQL Schema
  • "CONFIGURATION": characteristic of the target view. Contains the field name of the unmasked, scrambled anonymized field
  • "SEQ": optional sequence number used to order the list of the view fields
  • "VALUE": value related to the "CONFIGURATION". When "CONFIGURATION" is a field name, it contains an expression (or NULL when the field doesn't need to be changed in the target view) 
  • "CREATE": 'YES' when the target field needs to be created in the target table
  • "RENAME_TO": target field name when "CONFIGURATION" field name needs to be changed
  • "ACTIVATE": 'YES' when the target field "VALUE" needs to be used (when it doesn't start with the keyword 'PARAMETERS'). Otherwise the field name stored in "CONFIGURATION" is used.
CONFIGURATION contains one of the following keywords:
  • '#EXECUTE#': define the behavior of the procedure that will create the target view. When "VALUE" contains the value:
    • 'YES': it creates in the "TARGET_VIEW" view the fields with the 'CREATE' value set to 'YES'
    • 'ALL': it ignores the value of the "ACTIVATE" field ; all the fields with the 'CREATE' value set to 'YES' will be created with the expression stored in "CONFIGURATION"
    • 'RESET': if ignore the value of the "ACTIVATE" field ; all the fields with the 'CREATE' value set to 'YES' will be created with their original definition stored in "VALUE"
  • '#SOURCE_NAME#': when used, then "VALUE" contains the name of the table/view used to create the target view
  • '#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#': when used, then VALUE contains the expression used for anonymization (see SAP HANA Data Anonymization Guide)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

In the previous screenshot, the view V_SALARY_DERIVED will have the following fields and properties:

  • "ID" will remain unchanged
  • "NAME" will be scrambled and renamed to "NAME_SCRAMBLED"
  • "GENDER" will appear not changed in the target view
  • "CITY" will not appear in the target view
  • "SALARY" will be anonymized and renamed to "SALARY_ANONYMIZED"
  • "CREDIT_CARD" will be masked and renamed to "CREDIT_CARD_MASKED"

In order to execute the expressions to create the target columns, a line with '#EXECUTE#' was created.
Since the view contains anonymized data, a line with '#ANONYZATION_TYPE#' was s created.

In order to be able to use this table content into an Open SQL Schema, an SQL view in SAP Datasphere needs to be created : V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS. This view will contain all the fields from the table.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

2.2 - SQL Procedures

Three SQL procedures are created:

  • EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT: generates a create view statement 
  • EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR: with a string parameter used to filter the view V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS to create only one target view by calling the procedure EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT and embedding the code with instructions to drop the view if it already exists and generates the REFRESH statement if anonymization is used.
  • EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR: calls EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR for the distinct values of TARGET_VEWS.

2.2.1 - Procedure  EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT

This procedure returns the CREATE VIEW statement for one target view defined in the view "VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS" .

In the code below:

  • replace DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE with the name of your Open SQL Schema
  • replace DEMO with your Datasphere space name.
CREATE PROCEDURE EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT (
	IN TARGET_NAME_ VARCHAR(1000),
	IN CURRENT_SPACE_ VARCHAR(1000),
	IN CURRENT_SCHEMA_ VARCHAR(1000),
	IN EXECUTE_ VARCHAR(1000),
	OUT FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ INTEGER,
	OUT SQL_DDL VARCHAR (2500)
)
AS
BEGIN
    DECLARE PART1 VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE PART2 VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE PART3 VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE PART4 VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE PART5 VARCHAR(2500);

	/*
	CREATE VIEW PART 1: begining part to create the target view
	*/
    SELECT TOP 1 'CREATE VIEW '||:CURRENT_SCHEMA_||'.'|| :TARGET_NAME_ AS x
    into PART1 
    FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
    WHERE "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;

	/*
	CREATE VIEW PART 2: list columns for the target view
	*/
	WITH VIEW_PARAMETERS as
		(SELECT
			"TARGET_VIEW" AS "TARGET_VIEW",
			"CONFIGURATION" AS "CONFIGURATION",
			"SEQ" AS "SEQ",
			CASE :EXECUTE_ 
				WHEN 'YES' 
					THEN CASE WHEN IFNULL("ACTIVATE", 'NO')<>'YES'
						THEN "CONFIGURATION"
						ELSE "VALUE"
					END
				WHEN 'ALL' THEN "VALUE"
				WHEN 'RESET' THEN "CONFIGURATION" 
			END AS "VALUE",
			"CREATE" AS "CREATE",
			"RENAME_TO" AS "RENAME_TO"
		FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS
		WHERE "CONFIGURATION" NOT IN ('#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#', '#EXECUTE#', '#SOURCE_NAME#')
			AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_
		)
    SELECT ' ( ' ||
	    string_agg( IFNULL(RENAME_TO,"CONFIGURATION" )
	    	    , ', ' ORDER BY "SEQ" ) ||
	    ' ) as select ' ||
	    string_agg( 
	        IFNULL(
	            ( CASE WHEN "VALUE" LIKE 'PARAMETERS%' 
					THEN NULL 
					ELSE "VALUE" 
	            END ) 
	            , "CONFIGURATION"
	        ) ||
			' as ' ||
			IFNULL( RENAME_TO, "CONFIGURATION" )
			, ', ' ORDER BY "SEQ"
		) 
    AS x 
    INTO PART2
    FROM VIEW_PARAMETERS
    WHERE "CREATE" = 'YES';
    
	/*
	CREATE VIEW PART 3: select expression for the target view
	*/
	SELECT TOP 1 ' from '|| :CURRENT_SPACE_ || '.' || "VALUE" 
	as x 
	into PART3 
	FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
	WHERE "CONFIGURATION" = '#SOURCE_NAME#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;

	WITH VIEW_PARAMETERS as
		(SELECT
			"TARGET_VIEW" AS "TARGET_VIEW",
			CASE :EXECUTE_ 
				WHEN 'YES' 
					THEN CASE WHEN IFNULL("ACTIVATE", 'NO')<>'YES'
						THEN "CONFIGURATION"
						ELSE "VALUE"
					END
				WHEN 'ALL' THEN "VALUE"
				WHEN 'RESET' THEN "CONFIGURATION" 
			END AS "VALUE"
		FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS
		WHERE "CONFIGURATION" NOT IN ('#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#', '#EXECUTE#', '#SOURCE_NAME#')
			AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_ AND "CREATE"='YES'
			AND EXISTS (SELECT 1 
						FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
						WHERE UPPER("CONFIGURATION") = '#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_ AND :EXECUTE_ in ('YES','ALL')
						)
		)
	SELECT count(*) as x
	INTO FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_
	FROM VIEW_PARAMETERS
	WHERE "VALUE" LIKE 'PARAMETERS%' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;
	
	IF :FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ <> 0 THEN
		/*
		CREATE VIEW PART 4: add predicate for anonymization
		*/
	    SELECT "VALUE" AS x 
	    INTO PART4 
	    FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
	    WHERE "CONFIGURATION" = '#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;
	
		/*
		CREATE VIEW PART 5: list parameters for anonymization
		*/
		WITH VIEW_PARAMETERS as
		(SELECT
			"TARGET_VIEW" AS "TARGET_VIEW",
			"CONFIGURATION" AS "CONFIGURATION",
			"SEQ" AS "SEQ",
			CASE :EXECUTE_ 
				WHEN 'YES' 
					THEN CASE WHEN IFNULL("ACTIVATE", 'NO')<>'YES'
						THEN "CONFIGURATION"
						ELSE "VALUE"
					END
				WHEN 'ALL' THEN "VALUE"
				WHEN 'RESET' THEN "CONFIGURATION" 
			END AS "VALUE",
			"RENAME_TO" as "RENAME_TO"
		FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS
		WHERE "CONFIGURATION" NOT IN ('#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#', '#EXECUTE#', '#SOURCE_NAME#')
			AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_ AND "CREATE"='YES'
			AND EXISTS (SELECT 1 
						FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
						WHERE UPPER("CONFIGURATION") = '#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_ AND :EXECUTE_ in ('YES','ALL')
						)
		)
		SELECT string_agg('Column ' || IFNULL(RENAME_TO,"CONFIGURATION") || ' ' || "VALUE", ' ' ORDER BY "SEQ") ||' )' AS x
	    INTO PART5
	    FROM VIEW_PARAMETERS
	    WHERE UPPER(LEFT("VALUE",10))='PARAMETERS' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;
		
	END IF;	   
	
    select string_agg(x, ' ' order by rn) as x 
    into SQL_DDL from (
	    SELECT :PART1 as x ,1 as rn from DUMMY UNION ALL
	    SELECT :PART2 as x ,2 as rn from DUMMY UNION ALL
	    SELECT :PART3 as x ,3 as rn from DUMMY UNION ALL
	    SELECT :PART4 as x ,4 as rn from DUMMY UNION ALL    
	    SELECT :PART5 as x ,5 as rn from DUMMY
    ) a ;
END

2.2.1 - Procedure  EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR

This procedure creates the SQL instructions to create one target view.

It contains:

  • a DROP command that will be executed if the TARGET_VIEW is already existing
  • a CREATE VIEW command to create the TARGET_VIEW
  • A REFRESH command if TARGET_VIEW contains any field that needs to be anonymized

In the code below:

  • replace DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE with the name of your Open SQL Schema
  • replace DEMO with your Datasphere space name.
CREATE PROCEDURE EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR (IN TARGET_NAME_ VARCHAR (1000)) 
AS
BEGIN
    DECLARE SQL_DROP VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE SQL_DDL VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE EXECUTE_ VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE REFRESH_ VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE FLAG_DROP_ INTEGER;
    DECLARE FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ INTEGER;
    DECLARE CURRENT_SCHEMA_ VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE CURRENT_SPACE_ VARCHAR(2500);

SELECT UPPER("VALUE") as x into EXECUTE_ FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS WHERE UPPER("CONFIGURATION") = '#EXECUTE#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;

IF :EXECUTE_ IN ('YES', 'RESET', 'ALL') THEN
	SELECT 'DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE' into CURRENT_SCHEMA_ FROM DUMMY;
	SELECT SUBSTR_BEFORE(:CURRENT_SCHEMA_, '#') into CURRENT_SPACE_ from DUMMY;
    SELECT count (*) INTO FLAG_DROP_ FROM views WHERE schema_name=:CURRENT_SCHEMA_ and view_name=:TARGET_NAME_;
   
    /*
    DROP SQL expression to premare the replacement for the target view.
    */
    SELECT TOP 1 'DROP VIEW '||:CURRENT_SCHEMA_||'.'||:TARGET_NAME_ ||' ; ' as x 
    into SQL_DROP
    from DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS WHERE "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;

    /*
    CREATE SQL expression to create the target view.
    */
	CALL "DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE"."EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT"(
		TARGET_NAME_ => :TARGET_NAME_ /*<NVARCHAR(1000)>*/,
		CURRENT_SPACE_ => :CURRENT_SPACE_ /*<NVARCHAR(1000)>*/,
		CURRENT_SCHEMA_ => :CURRENT_SCHEMA_ /*<NVARCHAR(1000)>*/,
		EXECUTE_ => :EXECUTE_/*<NVARCHAR(1000)>*/,
		FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ => FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_,
		SQL_DDL => SQL_DDL
	);
	
	IF :FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ <> 0 THEN    
	    /*
	    REFRESH SQL expression for anonymization feature.
	    */
	    SELECT 'REFRESH VIEW '|| :CURRENT_SCHEMA_ ||'.'|| :TARGET_NAME_ || ' ANONYMIZATION;'
	    INTO REFRESH_ 
	    FROM DUMMY ;
	END IF;

    IF FLAG_DROP_ <> 0 THEN 
        EXECUTE IMMEDIATE SQL_DROP;
    END IF;

    EXECUTE IMMEDIATE SQL_DDL;
    IF :FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ <> 0 THEN
    	EXECUTE IMMEDIATE REFRESH_;
    END IF;

END IF;
END

 

2.2.2 - Procedure  EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR

This procedure calls the procedure EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR for all the distinct values for TARGET_VIEW.

In the code below:

  • replace DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE with the name of your Open SQL Schema
  • replace DEMO with your Datasphere space name.
CREATE PROCEDURE EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR()
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
AS
BEGIN
	DECLARE CURSOR c_cursor FOR SELECT DISTINCT TARGET_VIEW FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS;
	FOR rec as c_cursor
	DO
	    CALL "DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE"."EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR" (:rec.TARGET_VIEW);
  END FOR;
END

 

2.3 - Task Chain

In order to be autonomous to mask, scramble and anonymize data in Datasphere (without accessing to the Open SQL Schema) a task chain can be created to call the SQL procedure EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR.

2.3.1 - Grant permissions

Datasphere space needs to view and run the SQL Procedure that was created in the Open SQL Schema, some grants need to be done in SQL Developer by  the user DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE to the Datasphere space user.

In the code below:

  • replace DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE with the name of your Open SQL Schema
  • replace DEMO with your Datasphere space name.
 
CALL "DWC_GLOBAL"."GRANT_PRIVILEGE_TO_SPACE" (
	OPERATION => 'GRANT', 
	PRIVILEGE => 'EXECUTE', 
	SCHEMA_NAME => 'DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE', 
	OBJECT_NAME => '', 
	SPACE_ID => 'DEMO');

2.3.2 - Create a task chain

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

2.3.3 - Test

For testing purposes, we can use the parameters table described in 2.1 - Parameters table .

After running the task chain, the view V_SALARY_DERIVED was created and can now be imported into the Datasphere space (see 1.2.4 - Import the view into Datasphere ).

Finally your space should contain this list of objects: 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

If you open V_SALARY_DERIVED:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Conclusion

If you face some missing features in Datasphere, consider Open SQL Schema, it may offer you the opportunity to implement what you miss using the underlying SAP HANA Cloud database.

If you liked this blog, say it by clicking on the Like button.

entry.title: Best Practice Implementation of the SAP Geographical Enablement Framework - Initial Setup
entry.content:
Introduction

The SAP Geographical Enablement Framework (in short SAP Geo Framework), as its name suggests, is a framework that is used to add geo spatial attributes to any S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or S/4HANA on-Premise business object. This consists of configuration and ABAP class development for each object to be geo enabled. 

Because of the way an end user might wish to render an object on the map, and what business functions they wish to use from the map can differ greatly among customers and industries, SAP provides sample implementations of configuration and ABAP classes. This  provides out of the box working examples that can be evaluated, and used as templates for the customer implementation project. In many cases the delivered examples are not used in the productive environment, with a customer enhanced copy of the object used.

This blog series will be a technical discussion suited to consultants, and customer power users, involved in implementation of the Geo Framework. Reading and following the documentation is extremely important as the majority of implementation issues I have seen over the years are directly attributed to not following this first piece of advice. I will be focusing on the new S/4HANA 2025 release where we no longer require the installation of the SAP_GEF schema, and now have the spatial data storage in ABAP DDIC tables. Other than location of the spatial content, the majority of the information is also applicable for previous releases. Due to current technical constraints, query access to the spatial data is still via a native HANA view which now reside in the S/4HANA schema with a prefix '/1BCAMDP/GEF_' for easy identification.

The Geo Framework consists of 3 main components.

  1. An ABAP based persistence layer that is responsible for spatial relevant database access via ABAP ADBC calls. API's are part of this layer.
  2. A Map Provider implementation that consists of a web service and handles incoming requests and output processing. The default implementation from SAP is based on the Esri REST specification for a feature service. SAP only implements functions of the Esri REST specification required for internal use, but it may allow use by non-SAP tools with a customers own ICF node and subclass implementation, in conjunction with own method redefinitions in the Geo Object class. Other map API's could be implemented as an alternate or parallel Map Provider. Multiple map providers may be active at the same time. When a map provider API requires a license, the customer is responsible for any licensing agreements. The Geo Framework is a BYOL (Bring your own license) model since SAP relies on third party API's for comprehensive map provider visualization tools. SAP provides an Esri based map provider by default, given our large customer base overlap. If the SAP customer is already an Esri customer, then it is likely an agreement is already in place, but should be confirmed with Esri.  If the customer does NOT have a current Esri relationship and wishes to use the Geo Framework, they must engage with Esri themselves. There are a number of options for this, one being a subscription to Esri's ArcGIS Location Platform as described in the master note mentioned below.
  3. A Javascript based UI5 Map and Editor application for accessing spatially aware business data, external GIS data, and initiating business processes from the map. The map could be described as a context aware Fiori Launchpad where tiles are replaced by actions executed on the objects selected from the map. Essentially the map fills parameters to allow direct access to the business application, bypassing the typical entry screens.

Installation

The first step in implementation is to understand the components required for correct implementation. Reading  Master Note 3149622 should be one of the first tasks for the implementor. This note will explain the backend and UI components for each release on S/4HANA, which releases support which version of the Esri API the map uses, 3.x or 4.x, and which catalogs to use in role creation. It also provides information on SAP Web Dispatcher port mapping should there be a Central UI Server deployment. Customers running S/4HANA 2022 or later should use the 4.x API applications where possible. Esri has deprecated the 3.x API and SAP will discontinue supporting this version of the map application in a future release. If for some reason the 3.x API is required, it is possible to run both applications in parallel during a cutover period.

Enterprise search is utilized within the Geo Framework and needs to be configured as per the documentation.

It is strongly suggested that all outstanding notes released after your current support package be applied for the Geo Framework UI and backend systems. Component CA-EPT-GEF is used for the core framework and UI. Other applications such as Enterprise Asset Management have their own component for application related notes, PM-GEF in the case of spatial asset management.

I always suggest that before any major decisions are made that the sample configuration for the Business Partner be activated and tested. This ensures that the underlying framework is configured and running before you start activating configuration for other business applications, or customers own objects. Simply activating another application component Business function without the default Sample implementation will fail, as the Application specific BC sets rely of the default implementation to be in place. For example, all the Framework specific fields such as the Object Key and Geometry Context that are in the Application configuration will not be present and the BC set will fail to install correctly.

Spatial reference 3857 will be active in the S/4HANA database by default so for now there is no need to worry about an own SRS as the delivered OpenStreetmap basemap uses SRS 3857.

The start to installation you need to activate the Business Function FND_GEF and associated BC set as per the documentation. Depending on the activating user authorizations, such as cross client config, the BC sets associated with the Business Function may not fully activate. Check the status in the Switch Framework Browser. Below you can see everything is active with the yellow highlighted items indicating only certain clients are active. Clicking on the traffic lights will show activation status for each client. 

Should you not have all green check marks, you can go to the switch, by double clicking the highlighted node, and manually activate the dependent BC sets as per image below.

Press the highlighted icon and you will get the popup. Press Continue and you get the following popup. Make the settings as per image and Continue.

This will manually rerun the BC set activation, overwriting previous entry ensuring activation in the current client.

Go back to the Switch Framework Browser to verify the activation status.

Review and adjustment of Customizing

After activation of the BC sets it is recommended you perform a quick review of the customizing, and make adjustments as required for your particular instance. More on this further down.

The first configuration to check is the Geo Framework Map Provider settings accessed using transaction code GEF_GIS_CONFIG.

You need to ensure that the ICF node for the GIS Service Path is active in the system.

Ensure that the Esri data types were correctly loaded. These data types will be used to set the data types of the ABAP fields being sent to the map.

Ensure that all Framework Technical Structure Fields are present. These fields are used within the framework to move geometry data back and forth between the database, ABAP programs and the map. The Map Specific Data type is important and an incorrect setting here can produce strange behavior.

The next node is an alternate view of the Geo Object field mappings from the transaction GEF_FRW_CONFIG which allows you to view all Geo Objects configured in the client and mass process the field mappings, rather than individually in the Framework Configuration transaction. Here we see the two Geo objects for the person (PERSON) and Organization (ORGN) belonging to the Sample Business Object, Business Partner (BP) .

Field mappings for the PERSON Geo Object.

After verifying the Map Provider configuration, the geo enablement settings for the business data need to be verified with transaction GEF_FRW_CONFIG.

The following diagram shows the default configuration for a new S/4HANA 2025 system. Many sections are self explanatory and I will skip over unless there is an explicit change from previous releases. If you need more detail, please see the appropriate documentation page.

If you are upgrading from a system that was at some stage in the past an ECC system, your Schema Name in GDB may need to be adjusted. A new S/4HANA system will be installed with a database schema named SAPHANADB and is the default value from the BC set. ECC HANA database schemas typically used the format SAP<SID>, for example SAPEPR, and you need to adjust the configuration value to your system configuration.

The Maximum Record Count defines the number of records selected for each map tile query. Early versions of ArcGIS server (the default Geo Framework Map Provider is based on the Esri REST specification) by default limited the maximum records per query to 1000. Later releases increased this to 2000. SAP does not recommend exceeding the default Esri values for performance reasons. SImilar situation with the Enterprise Search Max Count values.

For those familiar with the pre 2025 versions of the Geo Framework, you will notice the new ABAP DDIC based database class and the upper case prefix and view name. The prefix when using DDIC tables is limited to a maximum of 13 characters to fit with the DDIC table name format. The last 3 characters are used for the geometry type to be stored in the table giving 16 chars total (3 used by SAP). It is suggested to keep the view name short but meaningful with the default being GEOM.

The system settings level database fields are now only for backwards compatibility. From S/4HANA 2025, the Business Object will be the default level for the database settings, hence there are none of the new geometry dimension settings at the System Level.

For the Icons for Symbols setting you need to ensure the s4 version of the icons are configured. Those upgrading from the older UIGEF001 map component may be using the mime repository path for the old version which is not present in a 2025 system.

Each Business Object now has it's own number range object with a single number range interval '01', replacing the single native HANA sequence used for the GEF_OBJECTID value. Please see documentation for number range details. The Business partner uses a default number range object GEF_GEN which will be used as a fallback if a business object configuration does not contain a number range. When migrating from HANA spatial table to DDIC tables, the number range status for each number range needs to initially be set to a value greater than the current HANA sequence value.

The Geometry Attributes section mimic the database settings of an Esri featureclass, defining the dimensionality and any default values when working with Z coordinates. Enhancements to the documentation on Geometry Attributes will be part of the future FPS1 documentation.

*** Deviation from default configuration ***

Since the initial BC set development, SAP has moved to CDS based search helps and the customizing in S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 requires adjustment. Updated BC sets with more examples will be coming in a future feature pack release.

For now we can make some adjustments that will provide more insight into the workings.

1. Update the Geo object settings to use the CDS based Enterprise Search model. You will notice a Z class for the Implementation class. We will cover this lower down but include in the change now. Make the same changes for both the PERSON and ORGN Geo Objects. The Z class will be the same as default with Z prefix (ZCL_GEF_BP_PERSON_SAMPLE and ZCL_GEF_BP_ORGANIZATION_SAMPLE).

2. Update the PERSON and ORGN field mappings to use the CDS Enterprise Search Models. You need to add mappings from the structure fields to the search model fields. Update your configuration as per the diagram below for the PERSON and ORGN. This tells the search to use the search field names in place of the structure field names.

3. Now we need to create new Geo Object classes as a copy of the delivered class. You will need developer access for this task. I will detail the PERSON in class ZCL_GEF_BP_PERSON_SAMPLE but do the same for the ORGN in class ZCL_GEF_BP_ORGANIZATION_SAMPLE.

Update method IF_GEF_BO_SERVICE~COMPOSE_GEF_OBJKEY as below. This will allow use of the CDS field name in the determination of the GEF_OBJKEY value.

METHOD if_gef_bo_service~compose_gef_objkey.

    FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_bp_number> TYPE any.

    IF mv_has_cds_esh_search = abap_true.
      ASSIGN COMPONENT 'BUSINESSPARTNER' OF STRUCTURE is_bo_data TO <fs_bp_number>.
    ELSE.
      ASSIGN COMPONENT 'PARTNER' OF STRUCTURE is_bo_data TO <fs_bp_number>.
    ENDIF.

    rv_gef_objkey = <fs_bp_number>.

  ENDMETHOD.

Create a redefinition of method IF_GEF_BO_SERVICE~INITIALIZE_ENTERPRISE_SEARCH. This will use the mapped field names in the search.

  METHOD if_gef_bo_service~initialize_enterprise_search.

    DATA: lt_filter    TYPE geft_geo_filter,
          ls_filter    TYPE gefs_geo_filter,
          lv_flt_field TYPE typename,
          ls_selopt    TYPE rsdsselopt,
          ls_selcrit   TYPE /plmb/s_spi_selection_param,
          lt_sel_crit  TYPE /plmb/t_spi_selection_param.

    " call super initialize
    CALL METHOD super->if_gef_bo_service~initialize_enterprise_search
      EXPORTING
        io_req_context = io_req_context.

    lt_filter = io_req_context->get_geo_filters( ).

* convert geo filter table into select criteria table
    cl_eams_gef_util=>build_selection_criteria(
      EXPORTING
        it_filter             = lt_filter
      IMPORTING
        et_selcrit            = lt_sel_crit
    ).

*-------------------------------- SAP Note 2831610 ------------------------------------*
* mapping customizing structure to Enterprise Search format
    IF  mv_has_cds_esh_search = abap_true
     OR abap_true = cl_esh_cdsabap_tools=>is_cds_connector( iv_connector_id = io_req_context->get_connector_id( ) iv_use_runtime_load = abap_false ).
      mv_has_cds_esh_search = abap_true.
      cl_eams_gef_util=>map_selection_criteria(
        EXPORTING
          is_mapping_dictionary = sc_bp_cds_esh_mapping_dict
        CHANGING
          ct_select_criteria    = lt_sel_crit ).
    ENDIF.

    cl_eams_gef_util=>add_filter_to_search(
      EXPORTING
        io_req_context    =  io_req_context   " Request Context for Enterprise Search: for Application
        it_sel_crit       =  lt_sel_crit   " Selection Criteria for Queries
        io_search_request =  mo_request       " Search Request
    ).
*    CATCH cx_gef_exception.    " (

  ENDMETHOD.

The remaining settings for the Business Partner Geo objects are described in the documentation and should be functional without adjustment.

The final configuration defines what is visible on the map for the user. This is managed via profiles and configured in transaction GEF_UI_CONFIG where you customize the map user interface. Please see the documentation for detail but I will provide brief explanation of the settings below.

It is suggested you add a server setting pointing to your UI system. This can be used to ensure the correct path for mime repository map icons is used, especially if deployed with a central UI server. In the above graphic there are servers for alternate basemaps, GIS servers and portals, but this is not required for the base configuration and will be discussed in later blogs.

The default basemap delivered is OpenStreetMap which requires no server settings, hence no entries delivered by default.

The basemap set includes the initial map location and zoom level on launch. You can adjust these values to a location more appropriate for your organization.

In the Icons for Symbols entry from above, I have enhanced with a server pointing to my base system as this is configured with embedded Fiori.

The default configuration comes with no Reference Layers configured. The default Business layer group contains the business layers for PERSON and ORGN geo objects. I will show this on the map menu.

In order to search for a location you need to configure a map locator service such as:

This configuration should now allow the default use of the map after allocation of appropriate authorizations.

Authorizations and roles

In order to use the map applications, the required authorizations must be configured as defined in the documentation. A role is required with Authorization Object G_GEF_GEOM to control access to geometry and is created via the template SAP_GEF_USR. Authorizations are also required for users with the task to create new spatial tables and views. I will cover these topics more in a future part of the series. 

There is no standard role at this time for the Geo Framework apps.  The catalogs required are described in the aforementioned Master Note (see the importance of reading this note ğŸ˜‰ ). It is suggested you create a role for the map/editor applications and another for the authorizations. There are no authorizations directly on the map applications, it is the content of the map that is controlled. Since different business objects may have different access requirements, there may be numerous geometry roles in addition to the role containing the map applications. You may also choose to create a role for the map and a role for the editor as a means of controlling edit access on top of geometry level control.

Now that we have configuration and authorizations setup we can test the map as per the Application Functions section of the documentation.

Let's explore the map

Here my user has roles for both the 3.x API apps (Spatial Asset Management) and the 4.x apps (Spatial Data Management). The Explorer app will verify configuration for displaying map layers and the Editor app will verify that the Enterprise Search is correctly configured. The Editor can select ANY Geo object that meets the geo object filter requirement. To do this, it does an Enterprise search with the field filter values in the selection parameters. The result list then shows which objects do and do not have geometry with a geometry indicator. From there you open the map at the default extent defined in various ways. This will be covered in another part of the series. The Explorer can only display an object that already has geometry.

Clicking on the Spatial Data Editor and searching for a Person we get the list of active Person business partners in the system. Select one and it will take you to the editor to add geometry. Select the point and click and save. Do this for a few items.

Then search for an Organization and edit geometry. For the Organization you will notice a context menu as this Geo Object has multiple contexts allowed. Select a context and create a geometry. Notice how the selected context sets the allowed geometry editing tools. After creating different geometry contexts, select the all contexts and see the overview.

Now we can display on the Explorer map and execute business transactions if configured. There are none in the BP sample but we will see this in the next article of the series.

Clicking on the Spatial Data Explorer we load the map at the default location defined in the Basemap set used in the default profile.

In this image we have the Business Partner layers shown in the menu. Note, the system I am using also has EAM configured so please ignore this for now. We will cover this in the next article of the series.

In this image we see the PERSON's on the map.

Click on the person and you will see the popup.

Congratulations. Once you have the ability to add geometry to an object, display the object in business layers, and see data in the popup, your system is ready for further customizing and additional Business Object implementations.

I hope that this first article was helpful in getting the base SAP Geo Framework up and running, and peak your interest in executing your S/4HANA applications from a map.

In the next part of the series we will cover the activation of Enterprise Asset Management Business Objects.
